image.altText: A vector illustration of blue, red and grey lines laid over spherical glowing 3D world map on plain black background.

props.synopsis: The internet powers almost every aspect of our modern life and is key for governments, intelligence agencies, and banks – and there's a worldwide struggle for control happening under the radar and under the waves.

title.children: China and the US are wrestling over a web of cables we never see, but rely on every day

image.altText: Escalators at Carindale shopping centre busy with Christmas shoppers

props.synopsis: Whatever today's economic data shows about how close Australia is to recession the truth is we are already experiencing the biggest dive in living standards in half a century — and have been for two years, writes Peter Martin.

title.children: We're experiencing the biggest dive in living standards in half a century — and a recession is looming

image.altText: Australia's Sam Kerr waves up at the crowd in the stands after a Matildas game.

props.synopsis: Lawyers for Matildas captain Sam Kerr, who's accused of the racially aggravated harassment of a police officer in London, are attempting to have the charge dismissed and avoid a criminal trial next year.

title.children: Sam Kerr's legal team make bid to have criminal charge thrown out

image.altText: Young baby at Childcare, Queenstown

props.synopsis: A childcare centre practice colloquially known as "under the roof" to calculate the ratio of educators to children is being misused in childcare centres, according to respondents of an investigation by 7.30.

title.children: 'Illegally operating every day': Here's what educators have told us about 'under the roof' ratio misuse

image.altText: A red sign with the words VOTE HERE TUESDAY points towards a church as someone walks in

props.synopsis: Voters across more than a dozen US states are casting their ballots today to decide who they want as the Republican and Democratic party candidates at the presidential election in November. Follow live.

title.children: Super Tuesday elections underway as Trump and Biden home in on presidential nominations

image.altText: a cricket match where an ad for parimatch is visible as a virtual billboard

props.synopsis: The federal communications watchdog examines whether Foxtel breached gambling laws by broadcasting ads for two illegal offshore betting companies during a test cricket match between Australia and New Zealand.

title.children: Foxtel under fire for broadcasting ads for illegal offshore betting companies

image.altText: optus 'yes' sign on glass fronted office block

props.synopsis: Optus has been fined $1.5 million after the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) found it left customers at risk.

title.children: Optus fined $1.5 million for public safety breaches, customers 'at risk'

image.altText: The tail of a Qantas plane in front of a Qantas shed on a tarmac at an airport.

props.synopsis: A NSW District Court judge rules that Qantas acted illegally when it sidelined an employee after he raised safety concerns about COVID-19.

title.children: Qantas fined $250,000, convicted for standing down a worker concerned about COVID

image.altText: Colourful illustrations of five beautiful women. All wear either a dupatta, chador, niqab, khimar or jilbab

props.synopsis: For Muslim women, wearing the hijab can bring a sense of pride, but it can also attract racism as misconceptions and assumptions prevail. So, let's set the record straight.

title.children: The question Muslim women dread every summer

image.altText: A man wearing a face mask is looking at a Southern Cross Station train platform

props.synopsis: Melbourne's Southern Cross Station is a gateway for commuters and visitors to the city, but experts say secret data shows the air quality poses a health risk to workers and passengers.

title.children: Melbourne's Southern Cross Station is notorious for its smell — now air quality data shows why

image.altText: Triple zero number about to be called on a mobile phone.

props.synopsis: Telstra says its triple-0 call centre was overwhelmed last Friday morning, with the telco's CEO saying a series of system failures contributed to the 90-minute outage and the worst failure of the system that she was aware of.

title.children: Litany of failures 'not of this magnitude before' and still under investigation caused triple-0 outage, Telstra CEO says

image.altText: A mum hugs her three children in a driveway.

props.synopsis: Queensland pledged to criminalise coercive behaviour after the murder of Hannah Clarke and her three children. The move will be closely watched by other jurisdictions.

title.children: Queensland is about to become the second jurisdiction in Australia to criminalise coercive control

image.altText: A young woman with brown hair folds washing while on her phone and sitting at a home office desk.

props.synopsis: Using micro-breaks to stay on top of domestic chores when working from home not only improves your work-life balance, it can also help boost your productivity and focus.

title.children: Why doing little chores while WFH is actually good for you

image.altText: A woman with a neutral expression standing in front of a flowering bush.

props.synopsis: It's taken Dassi Erlich a long time to stop blaming herself for the sexual abuse perpetrated by her former school principal, Malka Leifer. But the support of her family has helped her find strength.

title.children: Raised in a sect where women couldn't be loud, Dassi Erlich found the strength to bring down Malka Leifer

image.altText: A film still of Mia McKenna-Bruce, smiling slightly as she lies on a pool chair, a balloon in her hands.

props.synopsis: Director Molly Manning Walker's debut film doesn't shy away from the hard questions about sex and consent.

title.children: Director Molly Manning Walker hopes her prize-winning film will help women have better sex

image.altText: two women on stage

props.synopsis: The weight-loss journey of a movie star, who dropped an astonishing 50 kilograms in a year, captivates people across China.

title.children: Actress drops 50kgs for Chinese film hit You Only Live Once

image.altText: A close up, out of focus look at three social media app logos, Instagram, Messenger and Facebook

props.synopsis: Meta-owned Facebook and Instagram have resolved a more than two-hour outage that was caused by a technical issue and impacted hundreds of thousands of users globally.

title.children: White House National Security Council monitoring after Meta outage

image.altText: A group of long-stemmed wine glasses containing red wine being clinked together in a "cheers" salute.

props.synopsis: With the equivalent of more than 860 Olympic swimming pools worth of wine in storage and growers being paid 1970s prices for grapes, the industry is in a crisis bordering on catastrophe.

title.children: Nothing to cheer, as two-billion-litre glut of red wine sparks calls for halt on new vine plantings

image.altText: A closeup of Greens party member Max Chandler-Mather at a press conference.

props.synopsis: The Greens want the federal government to enter the property development game as part of a new housing policy to be unveiled on Wednesday afternoon.

title.children: The Greens want the government to compete with private property developers

image.altText: Rachel Angus smiles, looking fresh, in a selfie taken indoors.

props.synopsis: Menopause has become "over-medicalised" and treated like a "disease", Australian researchers are arguing, saying some women are getting unnecessary treatment. But it's a controversial opinion.

title.children: Women are being prescribed menopause hormone therapy unnecessarily, medical journal argues

image.altText: A representation of virtual currency Bitcoin and US banknotes.

props.synopsis: A fall on Wall Street is likely to send Australian stocks lower, while the Bureau of Statistics releases the fourth-quarter GDP data. Bitcoin plunges 14 per cent hours after hitting a record high. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: Bitcoin hits record high above $US69,000 before plunging, ASX set for weak start on Nasdaq drop

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Qantas conviction a 'game changer' for workers: Transport Workers' Union
Qantas convicted and fined $250K for illegally sacking worker concerned about COVID

image.altText: A composite pic of phone screens with social media app logos against a red background

props.synopsis: A report has found a mismatch between what parents and teens think are the biggest issues facing young people. While parents point the finger at social media, kids say it's study, the future and money that keep them up at night.

title.children: What parents worry about and what teens say concern them are worlds apart

image.altText: Tennis player Simona Halep clenches her fist during a match at Wimbledon. She wears a white dress and visor.

props.synopsis: Former world number one Simona Halep can return to tennis after her appeal to the Court of Arbitration to Sport is partially upheld, finding she likely consumed a banned substance unintentionally.

title.children: Former world number one's 'nightmare' is over after appeal against doping ban is upheld

image.altText: A woman with dark hair wearing a light colour Akubra hat and long sleeved white sun safe shirt.

props.synopsis: Graham Newsome died in 2017,  just 11 weeks after beginning treatment for metastatic melanoma. His heartbroken daughter is campaigning to raise awareness about the importance of sun safety.

title.children: Melanoma death of 'short-sleeve, stubbies-wearing' Queensland man has daughter spreading sun safe message

image.altText: Sydney FC A-League Women players celebrate with the championship trophy.

props.synopsis: Players from across Australia's top-tier women's football have reiterated their urgent need for a full-time competition.

title.children: 'The potential is huge': Players call for ALW to become full-time competition, again

image.altText: Michael Ross, a bald man, and Zaachariaha Fielding, an Aboriginal man, holding a scarf above his head.

props.synopsis: Electric Fields are "buzzed with euphoria" over being named Australia's Eurovision pick years after their first attempt, with dance anthem One Milkali (One Blood).

title.children: The ethereal electro-pop duo representing Australia at Eurovision this year

image.altText: Marine scientist Jodi Salmond standing in front of a glacier in Antarctica.

props.synopsis: A marine scientist says her experience on an old research vessel with women from around the world has brought home the need for greater focus on conservation and female leadership.

title.children: Antarctic journey with women leaders inspires scientist to take career to next level

image.altText: A still image from an SA Police bodycam video showing a man who was tasered.

props.synopsis: SA Police defends its rising use of tasers, after the ABC obtained video of officers tasering a man who was on crutches. One Adelaide criminal lawyer says others have been seriously injured after getting tasered.

title.children: 'Like someone squeezed the air out of my lungs': Man describes being tasered in the back by police while on crutches

image.altText: A map shows a section of ocean highlighted as the offshore wind zone.

props.synopsis: The government says the 1,000 square-kilometre zone could generate enough energy to power up to two million homes.

title.children: Heavily reduced Southern Ocean offshore wind zone officially locked in

image.altText: Security stands in front of Western Sydney Wanderers fans at an A-League game as a flare goes off.

props.synopsis: Western Sydney Wanderers chief executive Scott Hudson is calling on Venues NSW to overturn bans handed out to six members of the club's active supporter group.

title.children: Red and Black Bloc to boycott Wanderers games until 'unfair' fan bans overturned

image.altText: Mother and daughter take a photo in a creek.

props.synopsis: Alicia May filmed the swim with her children at a popular creek, but it was only when she was watching the footage that she spotted a dark shape lurking beneath the surface. Wildlife officers later estimated it to be a 3m crocodile.

title.children: Mother swimming with children unknowingly films 'sizeable' crocodile at popular Townsville swimming spot

image.altText: Black-and-white image of a swimming pool with people in Sydney Harbour.

props.synopsis: Billions of dollars need to be spent on repairing and replacing around 500 public pools over the next decade, so what does the future hold for the much-loved sporting and social hubs?

title.children: Australians are champion swimmers, but the pools they train in are closing
